bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A person who accepts a nomination for election to office as a Provincial or
          municipal official must make a written disclosure and file it with the person's nomination
          papers.

Promptly after receiving a written disclosure under subsection (1), the person
          receiving it must send it to the appropriate disclosure clerk.

A person who is a municipal official, public employee or municipal employee must
          make and file a written disclosure between January 1 and 15 in each year in which the
          person is an official or employee.

A person who becomes a public employee or a municipal employee must make and file
          a written disclosure not later than the 15th day of the month following the month in which
          the person becomes a public employee or a municipal employee.

A person who ceases to be a municipal official, public employee or municipal
          employee, for any reason other than the person's death, must make and file a written
          disclosure not later than the 15th day of the month following the month in which the
          person ceases to be an official or employee.

A person is not required to file more than one written disclosure during any one
          month.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Contents and filing of written disclosures: Provincial
bcl:section.bcl:text:
A written disclosure made by a nominee or public employee must be filed in the
        prescribed form with the appropriate disclosure clerk and must specify all of the
        following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the name of each corporation in which the person or a trustee for the person holds
          one or more shares;

the name of the creditor for each debt of the nominee or public
          employee;

a description and location of land located in British Columbia in which the
          nominee or public employee, or a trustee for that person, owns an interest or has an
          agreement entitling the nominee, public employee or trustee to acquire an interest.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
For the purposes of sections 3 and 4 and this section, a person is deemed to be a trustee
          for a nominee, municipal official, public employee or municipal employee if the
          person

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A nominee, municipal official, public employee or municipal employee may make and
          file a supplementary written disclosure.

The disclosure clerk with whom a written disclosure is filed under section 3 or 4
          must produce for inspection, on request during normal business hours, the written
          disclosure filed by a nominee or municipal official.

Subject to subsections (3) and (4) and sections 9, 10 and 11, a person
          does not have access to a written disclosure filed by a public employee or municipal
          employee.

On receiving a written disclosure by a public employee, the Provincial Secretary
          must send a copy of it to the member of the Executive Council who, in the Provincial
          Secretary's opinion, is responsible to the Executive Council for the administration of the
          Act for which the public employee is employed or appointed.

On receiving a written disclosure by a municipal employee, the disclosure clerk
          must send a copy of it to the members of the council, board or trust council responsible
          for the employment or appointment of the municipal employee.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
This Act is supplementary to and does not affect a duty or obligation to disclose an
        interest under any other law.

The failure of a municipal official, public employee or municipal employee to comply
        with this Act does not, of itself, invalidate a matter, proceeding, vote or
        contract.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A person who, as a municipal official, public employee or municipal employee,
          fails to make or file a written disclosure under this Act, commits an offence.

A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on
          conviction to a fine of not more than $10 000.

It is a defence to a charge under section 9 to show that the
          municipal official, public employee or municipal employee complied with section 3 or 4 to
          the best of the official's or employee's knowledge or belief.

If a public employee or municipal employee is prosecuted under section 9, the
          Provincial Secretary or appropriate disclosure clerk, at the request of the court, must
          send to the court the written disclosure of the employee.

If, in a prosecution under section 9, it is alleged that a person was a trustee for
          a municipal official, public employee or municipal employee, the onus is on the municipal
          official, public employee or municipal employee to show that the person was not a trustee
          on the official's or employee's behalf.

If a public employee or municipal employee is prosecuted under section 9, the
          court may make public all or part of the public employee's or municipal employee's written
          disclosure.
